Award.AwardTitle: A Multidisciplinary Platform for Wave Energy Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to promote undergraduate education in wave energy for science, engineering, technology, and education majors. It is designed to produce a next-generation workforce that can meet the ever-increasing energy needs of this nation. A multi-disciplinary team of six faculty members is assembled to undertake this educational effort. It is serving the needs of a large number of students in three colleges (Sciences, Engineering, and Education) at Old Dominion University.

Building upon their on-going research on wave energy, the faculty members on this team are incorporating their expertise and research findings into the development of five innovative and self-sufficient course modules related to wave energy. Students are gaining knowledge, mathematical and computational skills, and hands-on experiences of wave energy through the learning activities inside and outside the classroom.

The intellectual merit of this project is the establishment of a pilot educational platform on wave energy that integrates curriculum development, computer simulation, educational design, field observation, and community outreach. The success of this project provides a model for multidisciplinary collaboration on renewable energy education that can effectively contribute to the national needs in STEM education and that can be widely adopted or implemented in other higher educational institutions.

The broader impacts of this project are represented by the strong STEM education community that involves nearby HBCUs, Virginia community colleges, local military bases and industries, and high school young scholars. Special efforts are made to attract a large and diverse body of students into this education program, especially those from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aims to promote undergraduate education of wave energy for the science, engineering, technology, and education majors, and train the next-generation workforce to meet the ever-increasing energy needs. A team of six faculty members from the Departments of Mathematics and Statistics, Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, and STEM Education and Professional Studies at Old Domion University collaborated on this multidisciplinary effort.

The project developed four innovative, self-sufficient, and portable class modules pertaining to wave energy that include: Module 1 - Technology of Wave Energy: Social and Political Impacts; Moduel 2 - Fluid Motion and Wave Energy; Moduel 3 - Electrical Power and Wave Energy; and Moduel 4 - Wave Energy Generation Lab. These course modules were successfully implemented and delivered to several hundreds of undergraduate students across the Colleges of Sciences, Engineering, and Education at Old Domion University. Meanwhile, the project established a first-of-its-kind wave energy lab unit. The development of this lab unit combines hardware (physical equipment) and software (virtual environment), and integrates laboratory work, computer simulation and software application for the demonstration of wave energy. Since its completion, the lab unit has been extensively used in classroom and lab demonstration and other education and training activities related to renewable energy in general and wave energy in particular. It has also been used in many outreach activities, involving hundreds of high/middle school students at different states of the country, as an effort to promote the interest of the young generation and improve their knowledge in engery science and engineering. Additionally, the project produced a number of journal publications, conference presentations, and seminar talks, as well as a doctoral dissertation.

The project can serve as a model for multidisciplinary collaboration on renewable energy education that can contribute to the national needs in STEM education and that can be adopted and implemented in other higher educational institutions.
